author: sky.cactus
content: 1559 only smooths out gas price spikes between blocks. on the order of a handful of blocks.

author: sky.cactus
content: It doesn't address long term congestion or daily+ seasonality.

author: sky.cactus
content: It does make it a bit easier to get included without overpaying during a daily run-up, but i wouldn't say this is the primary thing it does.

author: 0xalizk
content: Im only talking about short-term bursts too.  Long-term congestion is layer-2/shards problem imo.

author: 0xalizk
content: It is clear block size elasticity will help dampen the spikes .. but the rising BASEFEE, imo, does nothing to dampen it .. demand for *this very next block* is super inelastic

author: 0xalizk
content: Users escalate `gasPrice` today, and will escalate `FEECAP` and/or `GAS_PREMIUM` under EIP1559.  I understand that the idea is that rising `BASEFEE` will "fracture and diffuse" demand .. but Im arguing, based on user behavior today, that it won't .. users will escalate and demand will cluster around that aforementioned "event horizon".

author: 0xalizk
content: Note that a burnt tax is IMO still good for the protocol in and of itself (eliminates block stuffing and out-of-band gas payments) .. so there should be a fee burn. Im just questioning its effect on the very-short-term demand curve.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@636212126939217941> 1559 will let the user specify a high base fee, but pay the minimum.  This means that if the current base fee is 1 nanoeth, you can set your acceptable base fee to 2 nanoeth.  This would mean that even if there were 11 full blocks in a row, you would still get in on the 12th block if it was not full.

author: sky.cactus
content: Full in this context means 2x "normal" where "normal" is block size over the past `n` blocks (a sort of moving average).

author: sky.cactus
content: This is importantly different from gas prices because with gas prices you always pay your bid, even if a lower price would have landed your transaction.  With base fee, you pay the minimum, not your bid.  This means it is "safer" to overbid in that you won't lose by doing so.

author: 0xalizk
content:
> 1559 will let the user specify a high base fee
<@!301186049323958275> by that you mean implicitly by specifying high `FEECAP` right ?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, I believe that is the one to set to achieve the above.

author: sky.cactus
content: IIRC, `FEECAP - GAS_PREMIUM = MAX_BASE_FEE`

author: 0xalizk
content: I still don't see how this fact eliminate escalation behavior I described.

author: sky.cactus
content: The only time there is a gas-war in a block (where miners will leave transactions out, and thus GAS_PREMIUM matters) is if the block is 2x as big as "normal".  This *can* happen, but it is pretty uncommon to see a *sudden* spike in transactions like that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, perhaps I'm misunderstanding your argument?

author: 0xalizk
content: Ya I think we're not looking at the same thing. So during normal or non-spiky but increasing steady demand, EIP1559 works, but so does the status quo.

author: 0xalizk
content: During those sudden spikes, that's where the escalation happens. What is it about EIP1559 that eliminates **escalation**

author: sky.cactus
content: Eh... I wouldn't say the status quo "works great".  You are correct it "works" though.

author: sky.cactus
content: EIP1559 is trying to improve the UX of those scenarios.

author: sky.cactus
content: 1559 doesn't do anything about sudden spikes, it is only trying to address the UX around the other 95% of the time.

author: sky.cactus
content: Escalator algorithm tries to address the sudden spike problem.
